{{About|an equation from financial mathematics|the unrelated partial differential equation|Fisher's equation}}
The '''Fisher equation''' in [[financial mathematics]] and [[economics]] estimates the relationship between nominal and real [[interest rate]]s under [[inflation]]. It is named after [[Irving Fisher]], who was famous for his works on the [[interest (finance)|theory of interest]]. In [[finance]], the Fisher equation is primarily used in [[Yield to maturity|YTM]] calculations of [[Bond (finance)|bonds]] or [[internal rate of return|IRR]] calculations of [[investment]]s. In economics, this equation is used to predict nominal and real interest rate behavior. Economists generally use the Greek letter <math>\pi</math> as the inflation rate, not the constant 3.14159....
Letting <math>r</math> denote the [[real interest rate]], <math>i</math> denote the [[nominal interest rate]], and let <math>\pi</math> denote the [[inflation rate]], the Fisher equation is:
<math>i \approx r + \pi</math>
This is a [[linear approximation]], but as here, it is often written as an equality:
<math>i = r + \pi</math>
The Fisher equation can be used in either ''[[ex-ante]]'' (before) or ''[[ex-post]]'' (after) analysis. Ex-post, it can be used to describe the real purchasing power of a loan:
<math>r = i - \pi</math>
Rearranged into an ''expectations augmented Fisher equation'' and given a desired real rate of return and an expected rate of inflation over the period of a loan, <math>\pi^e</math>, it can be used ex-ante version to decide upon the nominal rate that should be charged for the loan:
<math>i = r + \pi^e</math>
This equation existed before Fisher<ref>http://ia700304.us.archive.org/6/items/appreciationinte00fish/appreciationinte00fish.pdf</ref><ref>http://www.policonomics.com/irving-fisher/</ref><ref>http://199.169.211.101/publications/research/economic_review/1983/pdf/er690301.pdf</ref>, but Fisher proposed a better approximation which is given below. The approximation can be derived from the exact equation:
<math>1 + i = (1 + r)(1 + \pi).</math>
==Derivation== Although time subscripts are sometimes omitted, the intuition behind the Fisher equation is the relationship between nominal and real interest rates, through [[inflation]], and the percentage change in the price level between two time periods. So assume someone buys a $1 bond in period t while the interest rate is <math>i_t</math>. If redeemed in period, t+1, the buyer will receive <math>(1+i_t)</math> dollars. But if the price level has changed between period t and t+1, then the real value of the proceeds from the bond is therefore
<math>(1+r_{t+1})=(1+i_t)/(1+\pi_{t+1})</math>
From here the nominal interest rate can be solved for.
<math>1 + i_t = (1 + r_{t+1})(1 + \pi_{t+1})</math> (1)
In expanded form, (1) becomes:
<math>1 + i_t = 1 + r_{t+1} + \pi_{t+1} + r_{t+1} \pi_{t+1}</math>
<math>i_t = r_{t+1} + \pi_{t+1} + r_{t+1} \pi_{t+1}</math>
Assuming that both real interest rates and the inflation rate are fairly small, (perhaps on the order of several percent, although this depends on the application) <math>r_{t+1} + \pi_{t+1}</math> is much larger than <math>r_{t+1} \pi_{t+1}</math> and so <math>r_{t+1} \pi_{t+1}</math> can be dropped, giving the final approximation: :<math>i_t \approx r_{t+1} + \pi_{t+1}</math>.
More formally, this [[linear approximation]] is given by using two 1st order [[Taylor expansion]]s, namely: :<math>\begin{align} 1/(1+x) &\approx 1-x,\\ (1+x)(1+y) &\approx 1+x+y. \end{align} </math> Combining these yields the approximation: :<math>1+r=(1+i)/(1+\pi) \approx (1+i)(1-\pi) \approx 1+i-\pi</math> and hence <math>r \approx i - \pi.</math>
==Example== The market rate of return on the 4.25% [[United Kingdom|UK]] [[government bond]] maturing on 8 March 2050 is 3.81% per year. Let's assume that this can be broken down into a real rate of exactly 2% and an inflation premium of 1.775% (no premium for risk, as government bond is considered to be "risk-free"):
1.02 × 1.01775 = (1 + 0.02) × (1 + 0.01775) = 1.0381
This article implies that you can ignore the least significant term in the expansion (0.02 × 0.01775 = 0.00035 or 0.035%) and just call the nominal rate of return 3.775%, on the grounds that that is almost the same as 3.81%.
At a nominal rate of return of 3.81% pa, the value of the bond is £107.84 per £100 nominal. At a rate of return of 3.775% pa, the value is £108.50 per £100 nominal, or 66p more.
The average size of actual transactions in this bond in the market in the final quarter of 2005 was £10 million. So a difference in price of 66p per £100 translates into a difference of £66,000 per deal.
==Applications== The Fisher equation has important implications in the trading of [[inflation-indexed bond]]s, where changes in coupon payments are a result of changes in break-even inflation, real interest rates and nominal interest rates.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}}
